title: Australian newspapers redact front pages to ‘highlight government secrecy’
text:
Australia’s biggest newspapers ran front pages today made up to appear heavily redacted to protest against recent legislation that restricts press freedoms (Picture: Reuters)

Australia’s biggest newspaper companies have joined forces today to black out the front pages of all major titles in a coordinated protest against government secrecy.

Pages across rival titles owned by News Corp Australia and Nine today show redacted text and red stamps marked ‘secret’.

The campaign has been run after police raids on the home of a News Corporation journalist as well as the Sydney headquarters of of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

Police were searching for leaked government documents that formed the basis of news reports seen as embarrassing to the government.

The protest is aimed at national security laws which journalists say have stifled reporting and created a ‘culture of secrecy’ in Australia.

In the past, withholding information from the public has been justified by the government on national security grounds and today it said it backed press freedom but ‘no one was above the law’.

Advertisement

The media organisations involved in the protest said the June raids had been conducted over articles which had relied on leaks from whistleblowers.

One detailed allegations of war crimes, while the other reported an alleged attempt by a government agency to spy on Australian citizens.

The Australian’s Monday front page (Picture: Getty)

The Right to Know coalition, made up of Australia’s top media companies and industry organisations, is pushing for stronger protections for media freedom (Picture: Getty)

A former army lawyer has been charged over the leaks and on Sunday, the Australian government confirmed it was possible that three journalists may also face prosecution in the wake of the raids.

Today’s front page campaign is supported by several TV, radio and online news sites in Australia, and is being run by the Right to Know Coalition.

Michael Miller, executive chairman of News Corp Australia, tweeted an image of his blacked-out mastheads – including The Australian and The Daily Telegraph – and said readers should be asking: ‘What are they trying to hide from me?’

Nine, the company’s chief rival which publishes the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, ran similar front pages.

The newspaper front pages ask: ‘When government keeps the truth from you, what are they covering?’

Examples of secrecy include the government’s refusal to disclose which nursing homes haven been found to abuse and neglect elderly residents.

Every time a government imposes new restrictions on what journalists can report, Australians should ask: 'What are they trying to hide from me?' – Why I've taken a stand against increasing government secrecy in Australia https://t.co/BQek4KvKyB #righttoknow pic.twitter.com/cpXJEvz7pj — Michael Miller (@michaelmillerau) October 20, 2019

Advertisement

The government also will not disclose how much agricultural land has been sold to foreign entities.

ABC managing director David Anderson said: ‘Australia is at risk of becoming the world’s most secretive democracy.’

Prime Minister Scott Morrison said press freedom was important to Australia’s democracy, but added the ‘rule of law’ needed to be upheld.

He added: ‘That includes me, or any journalist, or anyone else.’

Australian media organisations argue that press freedoms have been eroded by more than 70 counter-terrorism and security laws that have been passed since the 9/11 attacks on the US.

The findings of a press freedom inquiry will be tabled in parliament next year.

description: Raids on journalists' homes and news organisations were authorised after a series of reports were embarrassing to the government.
